bibl.title: Military Orders for Wallace W. Forbes and Henry De Lamar, August 10, 1901

div1.p: Forbes and De Lamar are relieved from duty at Columbia Barracks. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Wallace W. Forbes and Henry De Lamar, August 10, 1901
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, August 10, 1901.

1. The following named enlisted men of the Hospital
Corps, U. S. Army, are hereby relieved from duty at Co-
lumbia Barracks, Cuba, and will proceed to the stations set
opposite their respective names, reporting upon arrival to
the commanding officer for duty, viz.:
Private Wallace W. Forbes, Rowell Barracks;

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
2. A board of officers, to consist of:
Major Alexander D. Schenck, Artillery Corps;
Captain John W. Ruckman, Artillery Corps;
2d Lieutenant U. Birnie, Jr., Artillery Corps;

will meet at the Headquarters Artillery Defenses of Ha-
vana, at 10 o'clock A. M., August 15, 1901, or as soon
thereafter as practicable, to examine into and report upon
the qualifications of Sergeant Michael Brennan, 17th com-
pany, Coast Artillery, an applicant for the position of Ord-
nance Sergeant, U. S. Army.

The proceedings of the board will be forwarded to the
Adjutant General of the Army through these Headquarters,
with as little delay as practicable.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Captain 7th Cavalry,
Adjutant General
